options: Allocating every dollar of income to a specific category until income minus expenses equals zero
questions.explanation: Zero-based budgeting means you give every dollar a job before the month begins. Income minus expenses should equal zero - not because you spend everything, but because you've allocated funds to savings, investments, and expenses. This ensures intentional money management.

questions.text: What is the envelope budgeting system?
options: Physical or digital 'envelopes' for each spending category with set amounts
questions.explanation: The envelope system involves dividing your spending money into categories (groceries, entertainment, gas) and allocating a specific amount to each 'envelope.' Once an envelope is empty, you stop spending in that category. This prevents overspending and builds discipline.

The 50/30/20 rule allocates: 50% to needs (housing, food, utilities, transportation), 30% to wants (entertainment, dining out, hobbies), and 20% to savings and debt repayment. It's a simple framework for balanced money management.

questions.text: What is 'pay yourself first' in budgeting?
options: Automatically transferring money to savings/investments before spending on anything else
questions.explanation: 'Pay yourself first' means treating savings and investments as your most important 'expense.' Set up automatic transfers to savings/investment accounts as soon as you get paid, before spending on anything else. This ensures wealth building becomes automatic.
